data.title: January sees record ETF inflows of $92B, fueling market optimism amid volatility
data.description:
Despite heightened volatility due to macroeconomic events toward the end of January, capital markets ended the month on a high note, with global stocks, bonds, and commodities posting gains. This positive momentum was reflected in a surge of capital flowing into exchange traded funds, which saw their largest-ever inflow for the month.

In total, ETFs took in a staggering $92B in January, marking a 142% increase compared to the typical $39B monthly average. The bulk of these gains were concentrated in U.S. equity ETFs, which accounted for $40B—approximately 90% of all equity ETF inflows. Within the equity space, sector-focused ETFs saw notable inflows, with $10B entering sectors, most notably Financials and Technology, which together garnered $9B.

Bond ETFs also experienced a robust influx of capital, drawing $37B in inflows—the second largest on record. A significant portion of this came from risk-on credit sectors, including a record $7B into bank loan and collateralized loan obligation (CLO) ETFs.

Perhaps one of the most noteworthy trends was the performance of active ETFs, which experienced a record-breaking $43B in inflows. This was driven by unprecedented demand in both active equity and active fixed income products, signaling a growing appetite for more hands-on, dynamic investment strategies.

As markets continue to rally, investor confidence appears to be strengthening, and ETF flows reflect the broader optimism surrounding global economy.

Outlined below are the world’s 20 largest exchange traded funds, ranked by assets under management:

No. 20: Vanguard Total International Stock ETF (VXUS)

data.title: Trade war tensions: How the U.S. China shift impacts global markets
data.description:
The ongoing U.S.-China trade war marks a dramatic shift in global trade dynamics, with China overtaking the U.S. as the world’s primary trade partner—reversing a long-standing trend where the U.S. held that dominant position.

Apollo Global Management’s chief economist Torsten Slok highlighted that back in 2000, the U.S. was the main trade partner for most of the countries around the globe. Fast forward to 2020 and data shows that China was the main trade partner for nations around the world.

As for the key U.S. import categories that may be most affected from China, they include areas such as computer & electronic products, electrical equipment and components, textiles, and apparels along with many other areas. See the visual chart below provided by Apollo Global Management:

Investors seeking to closely track the trade dynamics between the U.S. and China may want to consider broad market-tracking ETFs as well as those specifically focused on the Chinese economy.

On a separate front, The Budget Lab at Yale said: "The 10% China tariffs raise the overall price level by just over 0.1%, which is the equivalent of a decline in disposable income of $223 per household on average."

Market Tracking ETFs: (DIA), (DDM), (UDOW), (DOG), (DXD), (SDOW), (NYSEARCA:SPY), (NYSEARCA:VOO), (NYSEARCA:IVV), (RSP), (SSO), (UPRO), (SH), (SDS), (SPXU), (QQQ), (QLD), (TQQQ), (QID), and (SQQQ).

China ETFs: (KWEB), (PGJ), (CQQQ), (FXI), (GXC), (MCHI), (FLCH), (CNYA), (ASHR), and (YINN).

data.title: U.S. Composite PMI edges higher in final January print
data.description: The S&P Global U.S. Composite PMI edged up to 52.7 in January's final reading, vs. the 52.4 initial estimate and December's 55.4.

data.title: PureCycle announces financing transaction for $33M
data.description:
• PureCycle Technologies (NASDAQ:PCT) on Wednesday entered into a transaction anchored by Pleiad Investment Advisors, with participation from Sylebra Capital Management, and Samlyn Capital, to raise gross proceeds of $33 million.
  • PureCycle anticipates that the transaction will close on February 6, 2025.
  • The capital raised is expected to assist PureCycle in its efforts to continue bringing its patented dissolution recycling process to market.
  • PCT is +5.18% to $8.93.
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: Everest Group downgraded at Morgan Stanley after $1.7B reserve charge announcement
data.description:
Everest Group (NYSE:EG) was downgraded at Morgan Stanley after the reinsurer announced a $1.7B reserve charge in January.

"We believe the focus should shift toward how to successfully fix/remediate the U.S. casualty book. As the company looks for ways to improve the primary casualty segment, we believe the growth and underwriting profile will become muted for several years," said a team of analysts led by Bob Jian Huang.

"Separately, the reinsurance segment should also face a slowdown due to a soft market pricing environment. The combination of remediating the primary casualty book and softer pricing in the reinsurance segment should reduce the company's ability to generate short to medium term growth," said the research note.

"Primary casualty remediation may take a year or two to resolve, while the reinsurance pricing could also take a year or more to improve," the analysts noted.

Morgan Stanley lowered its recommendation on the stock to Equal-weight from Overweight, and reduced the price target to $340.00 from $425.00. The stock was trading 0.25% lower Wednesday pre-market at $340.88.

The investment bank has also reduced its 2025 EPS estimate by ~26% to $54.13, vs. $51.95 consensus, and the 2026 estimate by ~20% to $67.19, vs. $65.39 consensus.

EG reported Q4 non-GAAP EPS of -$18.39, misses by $0.97, and revenue of $4.64B (+26.8% Y/Y), beats by $600M, on February 3.

The average sell-side analysts and Seeking Alpha authors rating on the stock is Buy. The Quant Rating system grades EG as Hold.

data.title: Canada's service sector dips in January
data.description:
• Canada’s service sector experienced a second successive monthly decline in business activity.

  • In January, the headline Business Activity Index recorded 49.0. That was slightly up on December’s 48.2 but nonetheless represented a marginal contraction of service sector output for a second month in a row.

  • “Canada’s services economy experienced concurrent falls in both business activity and new work during January to signal another month of subdued sector performance. Panellists continued to note soft underlying market demand, with uncertainty weighing on business decisions. This may reflect ongoing unease over the impact of possible tariffs being applied on Canadian goods and services exported to the United States, and indeed this was cited as a real concern by service providers themselves. Whilst firms are looking to lower interest rates to help stimulate growth, tariff worries ensured that confidence amongst panellists remained well below trend," said Paul Smith, Economics Director at S&P Global Market Intelligence.

  • Canada records trade surplus in Dec; exports climbed 10-month high, imports hit a fresh record high.

  • ETFs: (EWC), (FLCA).

    Currency: (USD:CAD) (USD:CAD)

data.title: Beyond Air granted 180-day extension to regain Nasdaq compliance
data.description:
• Beyond Air (NASDAQ:XAIR) has received a notification from The Nasdaq stating that the Co. has been granted an additional 180-day compliance period, or until August 4, 2025, to regain compliance.
  • The notification has no immediate effect on the listing of the Co.’s common stock, and the common stock will continue to trade on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol "XAIR."

data.title: Nasdaq, S&P, Dow slide as Alphabet's earnings disappoint investors
data.description:
Wall Street's major market averages fell on Wednesday, with the tech focused Nasdaq bottoming the pack, after investors were left unimpressed with Alphabet's results.

Early on and the Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) was -0.6%, the S&P 500 (SP500) was -0.2%, and the Dow (DJI) was near even.

The 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) fell 6 basis points to 4.45%. The 2-year yield (US2Y) was lower by 2 basis points to 4.19%.

Major equity averages closed higher Tuesday as investors combed through another crop of corporate earnings reports while taking in stride news of China's retaliatory tariffs against the U.S.

"After a tricky few days for markets, the last 24 hours saw things begin to stabilize again, with most asset classes unwinding the tariff-driven moves around the weekend," Deutsche Bank's Henry Allen said.

Aside from the latest trade developments, markets got a further boost from the latest JOLTS report of job openings from the U.S., which showed the labor market remained on an even keel into December, Allen added.

Alphabet's stock fell (GOOGL) -7.8% and (GOOGL) -7.5% as the firm narrowly topped the Q4 profit expectations and revenues slightly missed expectations.

On the economic front, U.S. private sector job growth accelerated more than expected in January.

The January PMI Composite Final and January ISM Service Index are also set to be released shortly. The former is anticipated to come in at 52.4, while the latter is seen to rise to 54.2.

data.title: EuroDry announces agreement to sell M/V Tasos for $5 million
data.description:
• EuroDry (NASDAQ:EDRY) on Wednesday said it has signed an agreement to sell M/V Tasos, a 75,100 dwt drybulk vessel, built in 2000, for demolition, for approximately $5 million.
  • The vessel is expected to be delivered to its buyers, an unaffiliated third party, between mid-February and mid-March 2025, said the company.
  • Aristides Pittas, Chairman and CEO of EuroDry, said we expect to book a gain of approximately $2.1 million, or about $0.75 per share, as a result of this sale.
  • EDRY -7.20% premarket to $10.31.
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: Super Micro Computer ramps full production of Nvidia Blackwell solutions
data.description:
Shares of Super Micro Computer (NASDAQ:SMCI) gained around 9% premarket on Wednesday after the company announced full production availability of its end-to-end AI data center Building Block Solutions accelerated by the Nvidia Blackwell platform (NASDAQ:NVDA).

NVDA shares rose 2.2% to a premarket high.

The Supermicro Building Block portfolio, including a broad range of air-cooled and liquid-cooled systems with multiple CPU options, provides the core infrastructure elements necessary to scale Blackwell solutions with exceptional time to deployment.

In addition, a full data center management software suite, rack-level integration, including full network switching and cabling and cluster-level L12 solution validation can be delivered as turn-key offering with global delivery, professional support, and service.

"In this transformative moment of AI, where scaling laws are pushing the limits of data center capabilities, our latest NVIDIA Blackwell-powered solutions, developed through close collaboration with NVIDIA, deliver outstanding computational power," said Charles Liang, president and CEO of Supermicro.

Source: Press Release
